column4: I want to install ubuntu on an external hard drive, but my laptop's cd drive is broken.  How can I do that?
use a LiveUSB
what do you have installed right now?
XP Pro
use https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LiveUsbPendrivePersistent to make a USB drive that can boot Ubuntu (like a CD). then install it as normal
see section 6 there in particular
sounds good.  thanks.
basically, just download the ISO you want, have a USB drive big enough for it (you need about 550 MB free for the latest one, iirc), run Unetbootin, then fire away :)
i install it on the usb drive, take it over to the laptop, plugin both usb drive AND external hdd...then boot to usb drive, install to external?
that's about right. I mean, you can use your original computer too - just don't overwrite your existing OS by accident :)
could i just install the live directly to the external and install it on the laptop?  I mean, I don't think I have an available thumbdrive :P
you can do that. Unetbootin doesn't really care whether it's a thumb drive or a hard drive
ok cool.  thanks.
one last thing.  will it erase my external at some point? :S
erase it?
yeah.  i want the data on the external...and i have like 80+gb free...i just want to install ubuntu ALONGSIDE the data
when you say  you have "free space", is that space unpartitioned, or in a partition but just not occupied?
that's not going to be super-good for your robustness on Ubuntu. I forget if the installer lets you resize partitions
if it doesn't try downloading gparted and adjusting things
do everything at your own risk, of course :)
naturally :P
it failed...said ntldr was missing when i tried to boot it.
